project: SOURCE Connect Nodes and Mouse Events

Through a cruel twist of fate, you've found yourself in the middle of nowhere with no car and no sleep (you're a design student). All you want is to go to bed, but the only building for miles is a creepy old manor on the hill. You knock on the door, but there is no answer.

The door is not locked, nor difficult to open. You enter into a well furnished front room. As you close the door, you hear a click. When you try the knob again, you find it unmoving. Your heart racing faster, you go to find a window, but discover there are none. The noises of the rain and dogs have vanished.
Maybe it's the exaustion setting in, but you think you hear a voice calling back to you. "Who Dares?!" Certainly a strange response.
This hallway bears a dark forboding. As your legs begin to carry you through, you swear you can see words and scrawlings dance on the walls.
You hold still, curling into yourself. As you do, you hear a scraping sound, and a clicking. So much clicking. Your eyes ache and yearn for rest, but you try to open them one last time.
You feel a coldness upon you as light and darkness begin to intermingle. You fall into shadow as though it were an endless ocean. Perhaps you never were.
What is there to do but to keep walking. Your feet seem to be moving on their own as if they are possessed by the ghost of your own self. You stumble towards a door with many scratches on it.
Sit Down And Think About It

You can hardly believe your eyes: A Bedroom! The four posts are tempt you like water in the desert. But you feel just a twinge of guilt. Scattered among the floor are several papers, unorganized, unsubmitted.
Organize And Put Away The Papers

You feel a sense of thankfulness and the elation of a success of your resolve. You have done what others were not strong enough to do: finish the paper before going to sleep. You climb into under the covers for a well-earned slumber. Your eyes and ears linger on the doorway, for a moment imagining the face of a cruel specter in the doorway, but it does not come. Instead, sleep takes you, and you claim your first rest in almost twelve weeks.
Rain begins to pelt you. You hear an angry barking sound from elsewhere in the ground, followed by several more.
The rain begins to pound louder, drowning out other sounds. But then, as silent as death, you see the gleam of metal collars on nearly a dozen hungry hounds. Their eyes glow red in the dim moonlight.

The hounds chase you across the grounds. They are faster than you. Faster than you expected. You try to lose them in the garden. But they find you. You try to lose them in the hedges, but they find you again. Finally, they are only a few feet behind you when you see a small two story building with stairs leading up to it. The stone is slick from the rain. With no other choice, you attempt to climb up.
